key_facts: Corundum is a crystalline form of aluminium oxide typically containing traces of iron, titanium, vanadium, and chromium.
Goethite is a mineral of the diaspore group, consisting of iron(III) oxide-hydroxide, specifically the α-polymorph.
Limonite is an iron ore consisting of a mixture of hydrated iron(III) oxide-hydroxides in varying composition.
Hematite, also spelled as haematite, is a common iron oxide compound with the formula Fe2O3 and is widely found in rocks and soils.
Magnetite is a mineral and one of the main iron ores, with the chemical formula Fe2+Fe3+2O4.
Pyrolusite is a mineral consisting essentially of manganese dioxide (MnO2) and is important as an ore of manganese.
Rutile is an oxide mineral composed of titanium dioxide (TiO2), the most common natural form of TiO2. Rarer polymorphs of TiO2 are known, including anatase, akaogiite, and brookite.
Zincite is the mineral form of zinc oxide (ZnO).
Hornblende is a complex inosilicate series of minerals.
Tremolite is a member of the amphibole group of silicate minerals with composition Ca2(Mg5.
Actinolite is an amphibole silicate mineral with the chemical formula Ca2(Mg4.5–2.5Fe2+0.5–2.5)Si8O22(OH)2.
Ulexite, sometimes called TV rock or TV stone due to its unusual optical properties, is a hydrous borate hydroxide of sodium and calcium with the chemical formula NaCaB5O6(OH)6·5H2O.
Aragonite is a carbonate mineral and one of the three most common naturally occurring crystal forms of calcium carbonate, the others being calcite and vaterite.
Azurite or Azure spar is a soft, deep-blue copper mineral produced by weathering of copper ore deposits.
Calcite is a carbonate mineral and the most stable polymorph of calcium carbonate (CaCO3).
Dolomite is an anhydrous carbonate mineral composed of calcium magnesium carbonate, ideally CaMg(CO3)2.
Malachite is a copper carbonate hydroxide mineral, with the formula Cu2CO3(OH)2.
Rhodochrosite is a manganese carbonate mineral with chemical composition MnCO3.
Anthracite, also known as hard coal and black coal, is a hard, compact variety of coal that has a submetallic lustre.
Bituminous coal, or black coal, is a type of coal containing a tar-like substance called bitumen or asphalt.
Lignite, often referred to as brown coal, is a soft, brown, combustible sedimentary rock formed from naturally compressed peat.
Albite is a plagioclase feldspar mineral.
Labradorite ((Ca, Na)(Al, Si)4O8) is a calcium-enriched feldspar mineral first identified in Labrador, Canada, which can display an iridescent effect (schiller).
Amazonite, also known as amazonstone, is a green tectosilicate mineral, a variety of the potassium feldspar called microcline. Its chemical formula is KAlSi3O8, which is polymorphic to orthoclase.
Orthoclase, or orthoclase feldspar (endmember formula KAlSi3O8), is an important tectosilicate mineral which forms igneous rock.
Microcline (KAlSi3O8) is an important igneous rock-forming tectosilicate mineral.
Almandine, also known as almandite, is a mineral belonging to the garnet group.
Garnets are a group of silicate minerals that have been used since the Bronze Age as gemstones and abrasives.
Alabaster is a soft rock used for carvings and as a source of plaster powder.
Satin spar, less commonly atlas spar, is a trivial, partly obsolete name for fibrous varieties of the minerals gypsum, calcite, and aragonite.
Fluorite (also called fluorspar) is the mineral form of calcium fluoride, CaF2.
Halite, commonly known as rock salt, is a type of salt, the mineral (natural) form of sodium chloride (NaCl).
Andesite is a volcanic rock of intermediate composition.

Basalt is an aphanitic (fine-grained) extrusive igneous rock formed from the rapid cooling of low-viscosity lava rich in magnesium and iron exposed at or very near the surface of a rocky planet or moon.
Diorite is an intrusive igneous rock formed by the slow cooling underground of magma that has a moderate content of silica and a relatively low content of alkali metals.
Gabbro is a phaneritic (coarse-grained), mafic, intrusive igneous rock formed from the slow cooling magma into a holocrystalline mass deep beneath the Earth's surface.
Granite is a coarse-grained (phaneritic) intrusive igneous rock composed mostly of quartz, alkali feldspar, and plagioclase.
Obsidian is a naturally occurring volcanic glass formed when lava extruded from a volcano cools rapidly with minimal crystal growth.
A pegmatite is an igneous rock showing a very coarse texture, with large interlocking crystals usually greater in size than 1 cm (0.
Peridotite ( PERR-ih-doh-tyte, pə-RID-ə-) is a dense, phaneritic (coarse-grained) igneous rock consisting mostly of the silicate minerals olivine and pyroxene.
Pumice, called pumicite in its powdered or dust form, is a volcanic rock that consists of extremely vesicular rough-textured volcanic glass, which may or may not contain crystals.
Rhyolite is the most silica-rich of volcanic rocks.
Scoria or cinder is a pyroclastic, highly vesicular, dark-colored volcanic rock formed by ejection from a volcano as a molten blob and cooled in the air to form discrete grains called clasts.
Syenite is a coarse-grained intrusive igneous rock with a general composition similar to that of granite, but deficient in quartz, which, if present at all, occurs in relatively small concentrations.
Tuff is a type of rock made of volcanic ash ejected from a vent during a volcanic eruption.
Chalk is a soft, white, porous, sedimentary carbonate rock.

Coquina is a sedimentary rock that is composed either wholly or almost entirely of the transported, abraded, and mechanically sorted fragments of mollusks, trilobites, brachiopods, or other invertebrates.
Oolite or oölite is a sedimentary rock formed from ooids, spherical grains composed of concentric layers.
Travertine is a form of fresh water limestone deposited around mineral springs, especially hot springs.
Amphibolite is a metamorphic rock that contains amphibole, especially hornblende and actinolite, as well as plagioclase feldspar, but with little or no quartz.
Gneiss is a common and widely distributed type of metamorphic rock.
Marble is a metamorphic rock consisting of carbonate minerals (most commonly calcite (CaCO3) or dolomite (CaMg(CO3)2) that have recrystallized under the influence of heat and pressure.
Phyllite is a type of foliated metamorphic rock formed from slate that is further metamorphosed so that very fine grained white mica achieves a preferred orientation.
Quartzite is a hard, non-foliated metamorphic rock that was originally pure quartz sandstone.
Serpentinite is a metamorphic rock composed predominantly of serpentine group minerals formed by serpentinization of mafic or ultramafic rocks.
Slate is a fine-grained, foliated, homogeneous, metamorphic rock derived from an original shale-type sedimentary rock composed of clay or volcanic ash through low-grade, regional metamorphism.
Biotite is a common group of phyllosilicate minerals within the mica group, with the approximate chemical formula K(Mg,Fe)3AlSi3O10(F,OH)2.
Lepidolite is the common name for a lilac-gray or rose-colored series of minerals in the mica group.
Muscovite (also known as common mica, isinglass, or potash mica) is a hydrated phyllosilicate mineral of aluminium and potassium with formula KAl2(AlSi3O10)(F,OH)2, or (KF)2(Al2O3)3(SiO2)6(H2O).
Copper is a chemical element; it has symbol Cu and atomic number 29.
Diamond is a solid form of the element carbon with its atoms arranged in a crystal structure called diamond cubic.
Gold is a chemical element; it has chemical symbol Au and atomic number 79.
Graphite is a crystalline allotrope (form) of the element carbon.
Silver is a chemical element; it has symbol Ag and atomic number 47.
Sulfur (American spelling and the preferred IUPAC name) or sulphur (Commonwealth spelling) is a chemical element; it has symbol S and atomic number 16.
Apatite is a group of phosphate minerals, usually hydroxyapatite, fluorapatite and chlorapatite, with high concentrations of OH−, F− and Cl− ion, respectively, in the crystal.
Pyromorphite is a mineral species composed of lead chlorophosphate: Pb5(PO4)3Cl, sometimes occurring in sufficient abundance to be mined as an ore of lead.
Turquoise is an opaque, blue-to-green mineral that is a hydrous phosphate of copper and aluminium, with the chemical formula CuAl6(PO4)4(OH)8·4H2O.
Vanadinite is a mineral belonging to the apatite group of phosphates, with the chemical formula Pb5(VO4)3Cl.
Augite, also known as Augurite, is a common rock-forming pyroxene mineral with formula (Ca,Na)(Mg,Fe,Al,Ti)(Si,Al)2O6.
Rhodonite is a manganese inosilicate, with the formula (Mn, Fe, Mg, Ca)SiO3, and member of the pyroxenoid group of minerals, crystallizing in the triclinic system.
Spodumene is a pyroxene mineral consisting of lithium aluminium inosilicate, LiAl(SiO3)2, and is a commercially important source of lithium.
Aventurine is a form of quartzite, characterised by its translucency and the presence of platy mineral inclusions that give it a shimmering or glistening effect termed aventurescence.
Agate is a variously translucent, banded variety of chalcedony.
Amethyst is a violet variety of quartz.
Chalcedony ( kal-SED-ə-nee or KAL-sə-doh-nee) is a cryptocrystalline form of silica, composed of very fine intergrowths of quartz and moganite.
Citrine is a transparent, yellow variety of quartz.

Jasper, an aggregate of microgranular quartz and/or cryptocrystalline chalcedony and other mineral phases, is an opaque, impure variety of silica, usually red, yellow, brown or green in color; and rarely blue.
Quartz is a hard mineral composed of silica (silicon dioxide).
Opal is a hydrated amorphous form of silica (SiO2·nH2O); its water content may range from 3% to 21% by weight, but is usually between 6% and 10%.
Rose quartz is a pink, translucent variety of quartz with a massive habit.
Smoky quartz is a brown to black, translucent variety of quartz.
Arkose or arkosic sandstone is a detrital sedimentary rock, specifically a type of sandstone containing at least 25% feldspar.

Greywacke or graywacke is a variety of sandstone generally characterized by its hardness, dark color, and poorly sorted angular grains of quartz, feldspar, and small rock fragments or sand-size lithic fragments set in a compact, clay-fine matrix.
Soapstone is a talc-schist, which is a type of metamorphic rock.
Bauxite is a sedimentary rock with a relatively high aluminium content.
Breccia is a clastic rock composed of large angular broken fragments of minerals or rocks cemented together by a fine-grained matrix.
Chert is a hard, fine-grained sedimentary rock composed of microcrystalline or cryptocrystalline quartz, the mineral form of silicon dioxide (SiO2).
Conglomerate is a sedimentary rock made up of rounded gravel-sized pieces of rock surrounded by finer-grained sediments.
Diatomaceous earth, also known as diatomite, celite, or kieselguhr, is a naturally occurring, soft, siliceous sedimentary rock that can be crumbled into a fine white to off-white powder.
Dolomite (also known as dolomite rock, dolostone or dolomitic rock) is a sedimentary carbonate rock that contains a high percentage of the mineral dolomite, CaMg(CO3)2.
Halite, commonly known as rock salt, is a type of salt, the mineral (natural) form of sodium chloride (NaCl).
Gypsum is a soft sulfate mineral composed of calcium sulfate dihydrate, with the chemical formula CaSO4·2H2O.
Shale is a fine-grained, clastic sedimentary rock formed from mud that is a mix of flakes of clay minerals (hydrous aluminium phyllosilicates, e.
The name apophyllite refers to a specific group of phyllosilicates, a class of minerals.
Beryl ( BERR-əl) is a mineral composed of beryllium aluminium silicate with the chemical formula Be3Al2(SiO3)6.
Epidote is a calcium aluminium iron sorosilicate mineral.
Kaolinite ( KAY-ə-lə-nyte, -⁠lih-; also called kaolin) is a clay mineral, with the chemical composition Al2Si2O5(OH)4.
Kyanite is a typically blue aluminosilicate mineral, found in aluminium-rich metamorphic pegmatites and sedimentary rock.
The mineral olivine is a magnesium iron silicate with the chemical formula (Mg,Fe)2SiO4.
Sodalite is a tectosilicate mineral with the formula Na8(Al6Si6O24)Cl2, with royal blue varieties widely used as an ornamental gemstone.
Staurolite is a reddish brown to black, mostly opaque, nesosilicate mineral with a white streak.
Stilbite is the name of a series of tectosilicate minerals of the zeolite group.
Talc, or talcum, is a clay mineral composed of hydrated magnesium silicate, with the chemical formula Mg3Si4O10(OH)2.
Topaz is a silicate mineral made of aluminum and fluorine with the chemical formula Al2SiO4(F, OH)2.
Tourmaline is a crystalline silicate mineral group in which boron is compounded with elements such as aluminium, iron, magnesium, sodium, lithium, or potassium.
Willemite is a zinc silicate mineral and a minor ore of zinc.
Zircon is a mineral belonging to the group of nesosilicates and is a source of the metal zirconium.
Baryte or barite ( BARR-eyet, BAIR-), also called barytes ( bə-RY-teez), is a mineral consisting of barium sulfate (BaSO4).
Celestine (the IMA-accepted name) or celestite is a mineral consisting of strontium sulfate (SrSO4).
Bornite, also known as peacock ore, is a sulfide mineral with chemical composition Cu5FeS4 that crystallizes in the orthorhombic system (pseudo-cubic). It is an important copper ore.
Chalcopyrite ( KAL-kə-PY-ryte, -⁠koh-) is a copper iron sulfide mineral and the most abundant copper ore mineral.
Galena, also called lead glance, is the natural mineral form of lead(II) sulfide (PbS). It is the most important ore of lead and an important source of silver.
The mineral pyrite ( PY-ryte), or iron pyrite, also known as fool's gold, is an iron sulfide with the chemical formula FeS2 (iron (II) disulfide). Pyrite is the most abundant sulfide mineral.
Sphalerite is a sulfide mineral with the chemical formula (Zn, Fe)S.
Stibnite, sometimes called antimonite, is a sulfide mineral, a mineral form of antimony trisulfide (Sb2S3).
